When you know your money’s secure, you can shop with peace of mind – online, over the phone or anywhere!

Stay 1 step ahead of scammers with these top tips:

How to spot a fake
  • Look for spelling mistakes. Real companies will do their best to avoid spelling mistakes in emails, social media posts and SMSes. So if you see a spelling mistake, it’s best not to believe what you read.
  • Check the source. Google the name of the person or company the message is coming from. You’ll easily get a feeling if it’s trustworthy or not.
  • Only use trusted payment methods. Don’t be fooled if you’re asked to load money on a gift card or pay in crypto currency. These are 2 payment methods scammers often request.
  • Get SMS notifications from your bank. That way, you will always know when money comes off your bank account and can look into any payments that you don’t recognise.
  • Keep your account details safe with the latest account authentication technology.
  • Never share your personal information with anyone else.
  • Never debit your account without your permission.
Your personal information will be processed in accordance with our privacy policy, which you can read here.
Online stores
  • Check for signs that the website is protected before you enter any personal information. When you visit homechoice.co.za, you will see that the web address starts with a picture of a padlock and ‘https://’. These are 2 signs that the site is safe to shop on.
  • Make sure that your internet connection is private by keeping your computer’s antivirus/antispyware software up to date.
  • Protect your login password by making it unique, changing it regularly and keeping it a secret. It’s best not to let anyone else log in as you either because you will be liable for anything they buy on your account.

Social media
  • Don’t reveal any information about yourself that you wouldn’t want the whole world to know. Scammers can use your photos and profile information to pretend to be you.
  • Personalise your privacy settings so that only people you trust are able to see your information, not strangers or people you hardly know.
  • Check the company/personal profile of anyone who contacts you out of the blue. They might not be who they say they are.
Phone calls
  • Install caller ID software like Truecaller on your cellphone. This software allows you to see who’s calling before you pick up and to mark certain numbers as ‘scam’ or ‘spam’ to warn other users.
  • Ask to speak to a supervisor if the person on the other end of the line makes you feel uncomfortable in any way.
  • Don’t let the caller rush you. It’s your right to go away and research what the person is saying before you accept it as the truth.
Sales Agents
  • Check that the Sales Agent is registered with the company they represent. homechoice customers can do this by calling our Sales Agent helpline on 0861 422 4368.
  • Never pay a Sales Agent directly. It’s much safer to pay the company directly. Our Sales Agents are only allowed to process orders through a secure online order form that keeps your payment information private.
Before you…
  • Click on a link or attachment, check that there isn’t anything strange about the name, web address or the sender’s details.
  • Enter a competition, read the Ts&Cs. Even though they’re long and boring, this could save you from being disappointed or signing up for something you didn’t mean to. We post the Ts&Cs for all our promotions and competitions here for anyone to read.
  • Apply for a job, double check that the job is listed on the company’s official website or social media pages. We post our listings on our LinkedIn page and our website’s Careers page.
